Title:
A new species of Antella (Steccherinaceae, Agaricomycetes)
from southwest China
Abstract:
A new polypore fungus in the family Steccherinaceae,
Antella tibetica sp. nov., is described and illustrated from southwest
China based on morphology and phylogenetic analysis. The species was
found from Tibet of southwest China, growing on angiosperm wood which
are not much decayed. A. tibetica is characterized by an annual growth
habit, resupinate basidiocarps with buff-yellow to yellowish brown pores
0.5Â–1.5 per mm, a dimitic hyphal system with generative hyphae bearing
clamp connections and subicular skeletal hyphae encrusted with fine
crystals, abundant gloeocystidia variable in shape, and oblong-ellipsoid
basidiospores. The phylogenetic analysis based on ITS + nLSU rDNA
sequences shows that the A. tibetica nested in Antella, forming a
monophyletic lineage with strong support (100% BS, 100% BP, 1.00 BPP).
The difference between A. tibetica and other members of the genus are
discussed. A key to accepted species of Antella is provided.
